text: In Search of the Soul's Edge

In 1859, Charles Darwin concluded 'The Origin of Species' with a bold prediction about the future of psychology. He wrote that the science of the human mind would eventually be placed on a new foundation—the foundation of evolutionary biology.
Darwin understood that if natural selection shaped our bodies, it must have also shaped our minds, our emotions, and our social behaviors.

The resistance to evolutionary explanations of human behavior runs deep, even among educated people who readily accept evolution as the origin of our physical form. There seems to be an invisible line—what we might call the soul's edge—beyond which evolutionary explanations are deemed inappropriate.

items: Opposable thumbs and bipedal locomotion—widely accepted as evolved
Aesthetic sensibilities—rarely discussed in evolutionary terms

text: Alfred Russel Wallace, who independently discovered natural selection alongside Darwin, eventually developed a compromise position that many people still implicitly hold today.

Wallace argued these capabilities required divine intervention or some other non-material force. For much of the twentieth century, this compromise held considerable appeal—we could be animals from the neck down, but something more from the neck up.

Recent advances in neuroscience and cognitive science have made Wallace's compromise increasingly untenable. Brain imaging studies reveal that our most cherished mental experiences—love, moral judgment, religious feeling—correspond to specific patterns of neural activity.

caption: Modern brain imaging reveals the physical basis of mental experiences

text: If our 'higher' qualities depended on something non-physical, they should not be so vulnerable to physical brain injuries.

The search for the soul's edge—that boundary separating the evolved animal aspects of humanity from the supposedly non-evolved higher aspects—has proven fruitless. Modern evolutionary psychology suggests there is no such edge.
Understanding the evolutionary origins of the human psyche may be uncomfortable, but it is the necessary foundation for a genuine science of human nature.
